findings.title: ST - Stops Transactions
findings.description: The transactions are initially disabled for all users excluding the authorized addresses. The owner can enable the transactions for all users. Once the transactions are enabled the owner will not be able to disable them again.

findings.title: FSA - Fixed Swap Address
findings.description: The swap address is assigned once and it cannot be changed. It is a common practice in decentralized exchanges to create new swap versions. A contract that cannot change the swap address may not be able to catch up to the upgrade.

findings.title: RLS - Redundant Liquidity Swaps
findings.description: The contract performs redundant liquidity swaps due to the `tokenLiquidityThreshold` variable being set to zero.

findings.title: RVD - Redundant Variable Declaration
findings.description: The `BuyTaxes` and `SellTaxes` variables are declared and initialized but are not used in a meaningful way by the contract.

findings.title: MEE - Missing Events Emission
findings.description: The contract performs actions and state mutations from external methods that do not result in the emission of events.

findings.title: RSW - Redundant Storage Writes
findings.description: The contract modifies the state of certain variables even if their current state is equal to the one given as an argument, resulting in redundant storage writes.

findings.title: ULTW - Transfers Liquidity to Team Wallet
findings.description: The contract owner has the authority to transfer funds without limit to the team wallet. These funds have been accumulated from fees collected from the contract.

findings.title: PTRP - Potential Transfer Revert Propagation
findings.description: The contract sends funds to a `marketingWallet` as part of the transfer flow. This address can either be a wallet address or a contract. If the address belongs to a contract then it may revert from incoming payment. As a result, the error will propagate to the token’s contract and revert the transfer.

findings.title: IDI - Immutable Declaration Improvement
findings.description: The contract declares state variables that their value is initialized once in the constructor and are not modified afterwards. The `immutable` declaration can save gas by making certain optimizations.

findings.title: L04 - Conformance to Solidity Naming Conventions
findings.description: Non-conformance to Solidity naming conventions can lead to reduced readability and maintainability of the code.

findings.title: L07 - Missing Events Arithmetic
findings.description: Events are a way to record and log information about changes or actions that occur within a contract. They are often used to notify external parties or clients about events that have occurred within the contract, such as the transfer of tokens or the completion of a task.

findings.title: L13 - Divide before Multiply Operation
findings.description: Performing divisions before multiplications may cause a loss of precision.

findings.title: L14 - Uninitialized Variables in Local Scope
findings.description: Using an uninitialized local variable can lead to unpredictable behavior and potentially cause errors in the contract.

findings.title: L19 - Stable Compiler Version
findings.description: The `^` symbol indicates that any version of Solidity that is compatible with the specified version (i.e., any version that is a higher minor or patch version) can be used to compile the contract. The version lock is a mechanism that allows the author to specify a minimum version of the Solidity compiler that must be used to compile the contract code.

findings.title: L20 - Succeeded Transfer Check
findings.description: According to the ERC20 specification, the transfer methods should be checked if the result is successful. Otherwise, the contract may wrongly assume that the transfer has been established.
